advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE COVER</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US AD. 1983 #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Hard disk version<br><br> "<font color="#666666">No matter how you look at it, KAYPRO is the best value you will see anawhere...</font>"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>More power for less money</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is an advert from the ILLEL store</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT, OCT 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>The first sentence of this advert is:<br> <i>The new Commodore 64 is the most powerful personal computer available to the businessman.</i><br> Which wasn't totally true, even totally false.<br><br> The picture is also totally unrealistic. Each detail sounds false.<br> The C64 never was a business system, but a perfect home computer. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> RADIOLA ADVERT. 1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (FEBRUARY 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> TANDY 1988 CATALOG</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.switchtech.us/Tandy1000.html" target="_blank">SWITCHTECH'S Tandy 1000SX page</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROUD FATHER</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> RUSSIAN ADVERT - PAGE 3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Taras Ponomarev for this advert</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JUNE 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #4</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Learn computers with a cool teacher" <br><br> "Alice, the Basic teacher"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ISAAC ASIMOV AD #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>This surprising advert is dated 1982.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MICRO7 COVERPAGE (SEPT. 84)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Micro7 was a french computing magazine in the 80's. In september 84, its first page was featuring the EXl-100.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"At the fingertip of the mouse..." <br><br> "... 16/32 bits technology"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (DEC. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"9990 francs the TO9. Colors included" <br><br> "Thomson. All the world in a present"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This advert introduced three new Digital professional computers: the <b>Professional 300 Series</b>, the <b>DECmate II</b>, and the <b>Rainbow 100</b> <br><br> Advert said: <br><br> <font color="#666666">All that personal computers needed were a few professional standards. <br><br> Until now, manufacturer have made personal computers that were a hopeful compromise between home and use business. But now, Digital Equipment Corporation offers the first personal computers designed and built strictly for professional use. And since different professionals have different needs, Digital is introducing not one, but three personal computers made to professional standards.</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> IN SCHOOLS #3</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> M5 PRO & M5 JR JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.pugly.juice.or.jp/pugly/oldpc/" target="_blank">Pugly</a> for this picture!</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a German advertisement for the BIT-60 and BIT-90 models. Atari VCS-2600 cartridges are scattered in front of the BIT-60 to show that the it is really compatible with the VCS-2600 ! But strangely enough, there is no picture displayed on the TV. Were these models really working ? ;-)</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FLYER</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.peekandpoke.org" target="_blank">www.peekandpoke.org</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ABORTED ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>One of the aborted advert campaigns for the 8048 was "Micromania".<p class="petitgris">Thomas Fischer</p></blockquote>

computer.description:
This computer is what is the ZX-80 to the ZX-Spectrum, but for the Oric 1. Tangerine developped this computer before they became Oric and produced the Oric-1. It was mainly sold in kit, without the complete keyboard shown in the photo, but with a little hexadecimal keyboard.
The unextended Microtan 65 couldn't use Basic (Basic65) due to its RAM limitation (1kb), so only machine-code was usable.
Te 1kb ROM contained TANBUG, a monitor which allowed to enter machine code programs. But with the unextended Microtan65, there was no way to save your work (not tape facility), so you had to re-type your program each time you switched-on the computer !

emulator.description: Microtan 65 emulator for Windows by David A. Brown
emulator.name: Tangerine Microtan 65 Emulator

computer.name: MICROTAN 65
